attributes.title: Evaluation of Pilot Outreach Initiative to Increase Citizen Service Requests in Baltimore, Maryland

q1.value: Evaluation of Pilot Outreach Initiative to Increase Citizen Service Requests in Baltimore, Maryland

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan outlines a program evaluation of a pilot outreach initiative for promoting citizen service requests in Baltimore, Maryland. The initiative is to be implemented by Belair-Edison Neighborhoods, Inc (BENI) and the Baltimore City Mayor’s Office on Criminal Justice (MOCJ). An important component of improving government service delivery is citizen requests. Governments often rely on citizens to identify where and when services are needed. Requests for service might range from addressing overgrown weeds on public property to responding to alleged criminal activity. To increase the volume of citizen requests (and ultimately the effectiveness of government services), BENI and MOCJ are engaging in a pilot outreach initiative aimed at increasing citizen use of 311 and 911 in the Belair-Edison community. The initiative involves distributing educational materials on using 311/911 that provide instructions for what types of services to call 911 and 311, how to make requests anonymously, and highlights information city agencies require to respond to requests. BENI and MOCJ will also host “block parties” in selected block areas.

q16.value: The main outcome of interest is call volume to 311 and 911. It is expected that the distribution of educational materials and block parties increase the frequency of requests for services. • Expected Outcome 1a: The distribution of educational materials increases the volume of requests for services via 311. • Expected Outcome 1b: The distribution of educational materials combined with block parties increases the volume of requests for services via 311. • Expected Outcome 2a: The distribution of educational materials increases the volume of requests for services via 911. • Expected Outcome 2b: The distribution of educational materials combined with block parties increases the volume of requests for services via 911.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested through a pilot outreach initiative, which covers twelve block areas in the Belair-Edison community. Blocks have been assigned one of three conditions:   Treatment 1: Educational material on 311 and 911 distributed in block area Treatment 2: Educational material on 311 and 911 distributed and block party held in block area Placebo: Educational material on BENI organization distributed in block area   The educational materials will be distributed by BENI and MOCJ representatives in the given block areas through canvassing and door knocking. The block parties will allow citizens to discuss service requests and make inquiries with representatives from various Baltimore City government agencies such as the Baltimore City Fire Department (BCFD) and Department of Public Works (DPW). Food and non-alcoholic beverages will be made available.   To select blocks for participation, BENI identified “problem” blocks in the neighborhood. BENI judged the blocks to have high volumes of vacant housing, overgrown grass and weeds, loose trash, open-air drug dealing, and disorderly conduct, among other issues. The twelve blocks were randomly assigned to one of the three treatment conditions with the restriction that blocks having the same treatment condition cannot be geographically clustered within a three-block radius. The implementation of the treatments and placebo will take place over the course of June 2018 and July 2018.   The date and condition for each block is as follows:[1] Block ID Condition Intervention Date 1 Treatment 1 June 20, 2018 2 Treatment 2 June 20, 2018 3 Placebo June 20, 2018 4 Treatment 1 June 27, 2018 5 Treatment 2 June 27, 2018 6 Placebo June 27, 2018 7 Treatment 1 July 21, 2018 8 Treatment 2 July 21, 2018 9 Placebo July 21, 2018 10 Treatment 1 July 28, 2018 11 Treatment 2 July 28, 2018 12 Placebo July 28, 2018   Given the small-N, the analysis will rely on Fisher’s randomization inference to test for statistical significance of the outcome (changes in service request volume). The change in request volume for the Treatment 1 blocks will be compared to the change in the request volume for the Placebo blocks. Similarly, the change in request volume of the Treatment 2 blocks will be compared to the change in request volume of the Placebo blocks. The outcomes will be measured and calculated at 30-day intervals post-treatment for 180 days.   [1] Block identification numbers instead of addresses are provided to prevent publicizing areas with problems.

q27.value: Belair-Edison Neighborhoods, Inc (BENI) and the Baltimore City Mayor’s Office on Criminal Justice (MOCJ)

attributes.title: A Survey Experiment on Partisanship and Expressive Voting

q1.value: A Survey Experiment on Partisanship and Expressive Voting

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Many theories of participation highlight expressive utility as a mobilizing factor. This survey experiment tests whether people will pay real costs in exchange for expressive benefits, even when the preferences they express will not be made public in aggregate form. In particular, the experiment looks at opportunities to express one's partisanship (and varies whether aggregate levels of support for each party are made public)

q16.value: Hypothesis A1: Partisans will pay a cost to express their partisanship when the results are private. Hypothesis A2: Partisans will pay a cost to express their partisanship when the aggregate results are public. Hypothesis A3: Partisans are more likely to pay a cost to express their partisanship when the aggregate results are public. Hypothesis A4: Partisans who opt to express their partisanship at a cost are more likely to say that they vote for expressive benefits. Hypothesis A5: Partisans who opt to express their partisanship at a cost are likely to report voting with a greater frequency.   Hypothesis A6: Respondents who identify more strongly with a party are more likely to opt to express their partisanship at a cost. Hypothesis B1: Non-partisans will pay a cost to avoid supporting a party when the results are private Hypothesis B2: Non-partisans will pay a cost to avoid supporting a party when the aggregate results are public Hypothesis B3: Non-partisans are more likely to pay a cost to avoid supporting a party when the aggregate results are public Hypothesis B4: Partisans who opt to avoid supporting a party at a cost are likely to report abstaining to avoid expressing support for a party in an election.

q17.value: Hypotheses A1-A3 and B1-B3 will be tested using randomization inference (one-tailed tests for A1, A2, B1, and B2; two-tailed for A3 and B3). Hypotheses A4-A6 and B4 will be tested using simple bivariate regression. All tests will use a p

attributes.title: The Political Appeal of Crime Policies

q1.value: The Political Appeal of Crime Policies

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Although various studies have documented the effects of insecurity on the policy preferences of citizens, we do not have a solid understanding of how politicians react to insecurity and its effects on citizens and of the political opportunities that security policies may offer politicians. Many analysts consider appeals to heavy-handed security policies an effective way of garnering support among voters as they respond to citizen concerns over violence and to shifts in public opinion towards punitive policies as a result of insecurity. In addition to allowing politicians to respond to public opinion, resorting to heavy-handed security policies may also be an effective way of communicating politician traits to voters, despite the undesired consequences these policies may have on levels of violence and human rights. Voters may perceive politicians appealing to tough security policies as more effective or committed relative to politicians who propose policies often thought to be softer on crime and these perceptions of effectiveness may affect how voters evaluate the politician on other policy dimensions. Moreover, security concerns may override other concerns voters may have and thus allow politicians to resort to security issues to facilitate their implementation of other policies. The goal of these survey experiments is to answer two main questions. First, do appeals to repressive security policies signal politician effectiveness in other (non-security) policy areas? And second, are appeals to security issues an effective way for politicians to garner support to implement other, perhaps unpalatable, policies? In answering these questions, I hope to contribute to our understanding of how politicians can use an issue like crime and security to shape public opinion towards themselves and towards other policy issues. To do so, I am including two survey experiments in an online survey of Mexican citizens. The first experiment asks respondents about their local mayor's effectiveness at administering a housing improvement plan, but some respondents are also told that the mayor is implementing a repressive security policy and others that the mayor is taking a preventative approach to crime. In the second experiment, respondents are asked if they'd be willing to support a tax increase to their cellphone plans, but some respondents are told that these additional revenues would help fight crime whereas others are told that it would help fight poverty.

q16.value: I group hypotheses around the main outcomes of politician effectiveness and willingness to accept a tax increase. Regarding politician effectiveness, the hypotheses to be tested are: -Respondents perceive the municipal president associated with militarized and repressive policing as more effective in housing policy than the municipal president associated with preventative crime policies and as more effective than the municipal president not associated with any crime policies. -Respondents perceive the municipal president associated with preven- tative crime policies as more effective in housing policy than the municipal president not associated with any crime policies. -Municipal presidents associated with crime policies (either preventative or repressive) are perceived as more effective than those not associated with any crime policies. Regarding willingness to accept a tax increase: -Respondents are more willing to accept a tax when it is associated with reducing crime than when it is associated with reducing poverty. I also test for heterogeneous effects since I expect the effects. For politician effectiveness, these are: - Respondents who think crime is the most important problem facing their municipality perceive the municipal president as more effective than those who do not rank crime as the most important problem. -Respondents who think crime is increasing perceive the municipal president as more effective than those who think crime is decreasing. -Respondents who live in high crime municipalities perceive the municipal president as more effective than those in low crime municipalities. -Respondents who think the government is involved in violence in their municipalities or that organized crime influence politics in their municipalities will perceive their municipal president as least effective relative to those who do not hold this view. And for the willingness to accept the tax increase: -Respondents who think crime is the most important problem facing their municipality are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who do not think crime is the most important problem. -Respondents who think crime is increasing are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who think crime is decreasing. -Respondents who live in high crime municipalities are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who live in low crime municipalities. -Respondents who believe that the government is involved in violence in their municipalities or that organized crime influences politics in their municipalities are the least likely to accept the additional tax relative to those who think otherwise.

q17.value: Because it's a survey experiment, the average treatment effect can be estimated through an OLS regression that has the outcome of interest as the dependent variable and a dummy indicating treatment status as the main explanatory variable. The regression can be expanded to include municipality fixed effects as well as interaction terms for the heterogeneous effects.

registration_responses.q1: The Political Appeal of Crime Policies
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Although various studies have documented the effects of insecurity on the policy preferences of citizens, we do not have a solid understanding of how politicians react to insecurity and its effects on citizens and of the political opportunities that security policies may offer politicians. Many analysts consider appeals to heavy-handed security policies an effective way of garnering support among voters as they respond to citizen concerns over violence and to shifts in public opinion towards punitive policies as a result of insecurity. In addition to allowing politicians to respond to public opinion, resorting to heavy-handed security policies may also be an effective way of communicating politician traits to voters, despite the undesired consequences these policies may have on levels of violence and human rights. Voters may perceive politicians appealing to tough security policies as more effective or committed relative to politicians who propose policies often thought to be softer on crime and these perceptions of effectiveness may affect how voters evaluate the politician on other policy dimensions. Moreover, security concerns may override other concerns voters may have and thus allow politicians to resort to security issues to facilitate their implementation of other policies. The goal of these survey experiments is to answer two main questions. First, do appeals to repressive security policies signal politician effectiveness in other (non-security) policy areas? And second, are appeals to security issues an effective way for politicians to garner support to implement other, perhaps unpalatable, policies? In answering these questions, I hope to contribute to our understanding of how politicians can use an issue like crime and security to shape public opinion towards themselves and towards other policy issues. To do so, I am including two survey experiments in an online survey of Mexican citizens. The first experiment asks respondents about their local mayor's effectiveness at administering a housing improvement plan, but some respondents are also told that the mayor is implementing a repressive security policy and others that the mayor is taking a preventative approach to crime. In the second experiment, respondents are asked if they'd be willing to support a tax increase to their cellphone plans, but some respondents are told that these additional revenues would help fight crime whereas others are told that it would help fight poverty.
registration_responses.q16: I group hypotheses around the main outcomes of politician effectiveness and willingness to accept a tax increase. Regarding politician effectiveness, the hypotheses to be tested are: -Respondents perceive the municipal president associated with militarized and repressive policing as more effective in housing policy than the municipal president associated with preventative crime policies and as more effective than the municipal president not associated with any crime policies. -Respondents perceive the municipal president associated with preven- tative crime policies as more effective in housing policy than the municipal president not associated with any crime policies. -Municipal presidents associated with crime policies (either preventative or repressive) are perceived as more effective than those not associated with any crime policies. Regarding willingness to accept a tax increase: -Respondents are more willing to accept a tax when it is associated with reducing crime than when it is associated with reducing poverty. I also test for heterogeneous effects since I expect the effects. For politician effectiveness, these are: - Respondents who think crime is the most important problem facing their municipality perceive the municipal president as more effective than those who do not rank crime as the most important problem. -Respondents who think crime is increasing perceive the municipal president as more effective than those who think crime is decreasing. -Respondents who live in high crime municipalities perceive the municipal president as more effective than those in low crime municipalities. -Respondents who think the government is involved in violence in their municipalities or that organized crime influence politics in their municipalities will perceive their municipal president as least effective relative to those who do not hold this view. And for the willingness to accept the tax increase: -Respondents who think crime is the most important problem facing their municipality are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who do not think crime is the most important problem. -Respondents who think crime is increasing are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who think crime is decreasing. -Respondents who live in high crime municipalities are more likely to accept the additional tax than those who live in low crime municipalities. -Respondents who believe that the government is involved in violence in their municipalities or that organized crime influences politics in their municipalities are the least likely to accept the additional tax relative to those who think otherwise.
registration_responses.q17: Because it's a survey experiment, the average treatment effect can be estimated through an OLS regression that has the outcome of interest as the dependent variable and a dummy indicating treatment status as the main explanatory variable. The regression can be expanded to include municipality fixed effects as well as interaction terms for the heterogeneous effects.

attributes.title: An Empirical Assessment of Preference Falsification and Self-Censorship: Experimental Evidence from Japan

q1.value: An Empirical Assessment of Preference Falsification and Self-Censorship: Experimental Evidence from Japan

q2.value: Sophia Hatz | Charles Crabtree | Atsushi Tago | Kristine Eck

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Research questions: To what extent do individuals change or conceal their stated opinions when plausibly under government monitoring? To what extent do individuals change or conceal their stated opinions when plausibly under corporate monitoring?

q16.value: H1: Survey answers differ between respondents exposed to information that the government might be able to observe their responses. Non-directional. H2: Survey answers differ between respondents exposed to information that a corporation might be able to observe their responses. Non-directional. H3: Respondents are more likely to conceal their opinions if they are exposed to information that a corporation might be able to observe their answers. Directional. H4: Respondents are more likely to conceal their opinions if they are exposed to information that the government might be able to observe their answers. Directional. H5: Respondents are more likely to leave a survey if they think that the government might be able to observe their responses. H6: Respondents are more likely to leave a survey if they think that a company might be able to observe their responses. - All comparisons are to the control condition, unless specified otherwise.

q17.value: We will estimate the average treatment effect of our treatments on our outcomes with linear probability models. These models will include mean-centered covariates collected before the experimental treatment. To make inferences, we use HC2 robust standard errors. When testing the equality of our treatments on our outcomes, we will conduct Wald tests.

These models will include mean-centered covariates collected before the experimental treatment. To make inferences, we use HC2 robust standard errors. When testing the equality of our treatments on our outcomes, we will conduct Wald tests.

attributes.title: The Lasting Legacies of Social Exclusion on Solidarity: Evidence from a Former Leper Colony in Colombia

q1.value: The Lasting Legacies of Social Exclusion on Solidarity: Evidence from a Former Leper Colony in Colombia

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Group identity has been identified as a source of social preferences. On the other hand, social exclusion is a source of group formation and thus group identity. This project focuses on the history of leprosy in Colombia to assess the legacy of the historical social -and geographical- exclusion on current solidarity and social capital. Leprosy has a strong genetic component and is correlated with poverty, a condition amply met by the totality of Colombia throughout the 19th and the early 20th centuries, so that the ‘historical assignment’ of the disease in Colombia -which inevitably came with social exclusion- can be understood as if random. Leveraging on the fact that all lepers were geographically isolated as a part of the social exclusion to which they were subject, and that leprosy has nearly vanished since the 1960s, this project seeks to investigate the differential effects of social exclusion on in- and out-group pro-sociality and social capital. Further, considering that such exclusion was strongly related to a medical stigma, the project also seeks to investigate the legacy of this medically-managed exclusion on contemporary trust in modern medicine.

q16.value: This project seeks to test several main hypotheses: 1. Historical experiences of social exclusion have a positive effect on in-group solidarity 2. Historical experiences of social exclusion have a negative effect on out-group solidarity 3. Is the positive effect on ingroup solidarity outweighed by the negative effect on outgroup solidarity when considering measures of solidarity that disregard group-considerations? (No prior as to which is the preeminent effect) 4. There is a negative legacy on trust in modern medicine in those sites of leper isolation Further, two mechanisms will be assessed: 1. Intergenerational transmission of social preferences 2. Knowledge of history

q17.value: The project will employ a lab-in-the-field approach to answer the hypothesis. Dictator Games will be conducted in the former leper colony (called Agua de Dios) and in the two municipalities contiguous to it (called Ricaurte and Tocaima, for a total of 3 municipalities), which provide a reasonable control group to examine the effects of social discrimination on solidarity. Subjects will be asked to divide COP $16000 (more than half a day of a minimum wage) between themselves and someone chosen at random in the same municipality (which measures ingroup solidarity). They will be also asked to divide COP $16000 between themselves and someone chosen at random in Apulo, a third Colombian municipality that has a comparable level of development and of climatic conditions (which measures outgroup solidarity). The comparison of these two measures across the three municipalities will enable to test hypotheses 1 and 2 above. Further, question 3 above can be assessed by comparing the aggregation of the within-town allocation and the allocation given to subjects in Apulo in the Dictator games. Such question will also be assessed by comparing across municipalities the answers to a survey measure asking for a degree of similarity (between 1 and 10) to someone who finds it important to selflessly help others. Finally, hypothesis 4 will be assessed by comparing across the three municipalities the answers to questions about trust on physicians (on a scale from 1 to 10), and on perceived danger of the vaccine against the human papilloma virus (again on a scale from 1 to 10), a vaccine that the Colombian government recently tried to implement in all of the country and that faced some resistance by certain individuals. As for the mechanisms, the subjects will be asked for the number of grandparents coming from Agua de Dios and for the knowledge of local history (on a scale from 1 to 10), which will allow to detect if the lower outgroup pro-sociality and the abstract (aggregate) measure of pro-sociality is coming from a higher ancestry in the town (i.e., a higher ancestry exposed to social exclusion) and/or through a higher awareness of history.

q23.value: This protocol was determined to be exempt from review

attributes.title: Anticipatory Arms Control: Explaining Preemptive Constraints on Breakthrough Military Technologies

q1.value: Anticipatory Arms Control: Explaining Preemptive Constraints on Breakthrough Military Technologies

q5.value: Michael Aklin, Clifford Bob, Alessandra Casello, Alexandra Chinchilla, Miguel Gomez, Donald P. Green, Kolby Hanson, Kyle Haynes, Sunshine Hillygus, James Hollyer, Robert Jervis, Danielle Jung, Joshua Kertzer, Nadiya Kostyuk, Susan Landau, Tolya Levshin, Erik Lin-Greenberg, Hanzhang Liu, Asaf Lubin, Rose McDermott, Andrew Nathan, John Patty, Kathleen E. Powers, Georgiy Syunyaev, Alexander Thompson, Jeff Taliaferro, Brandon Valeriano

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Scholars have long been aware of the strategic choices made by states when negotiating new international agreements. A rich literature focuses on concerns that adversaries will later renege on agreements. Using a formal model, I show that even in the best case scenario, when mutual trust is high (i.e. cheating occurs with probability zero), arms control deals may still fail. There exist several cases where technological breakthroughs were successfully regulated in anticipation of their respective demonstration points, sometimes while still in the design phase, or even prior to proof of concept. I advance a theory about a distinct mechanism: uncertainty about how frontier technologies might alter the security environment in unknown, and perhaps disadvantageous, ways. This theory would help explain systematic variation in the regulatory time horizon for new military technologies. The experiment I propose would test whether the hypotheses are validated more generally beyond the handful of historical case studies I discuss in the paper.

q16.value: Research Question: Assuming neutral priors on the future utility of a (potentially) disruptive weapons system innovation, how do (1) expected adoption capabilities, (2) expected diffusion propensities, and (3) revealed information about utility influence support for arms control? Hypothesis 1: Support for arms control should increase when the weapon originates with an adversary, and decrease when originates in a respondent’s home country. Hypothesis 2a: When a weapon originates in an adversary country, support for arms control should increase when expectations that it will diffuse are low, and decrease when expectations are high. Hypothesis 2b: When a weapon originates in a respondent’s home country, support for arms control should increase when expectations that it will diffuse are high, and decrease when expectations are low. Hypothesis 3: When a weapon is revealed to provide a disproportionate strategic advantage to a respondent’s country, support for arms control should decrease. When it conveys a disadvantage, support for arms control should increase.

q17.value: The study will involve a pair of experiments: first, a 2x2 factorial experimental design, followed by a standard two-condition design meant to test the second stage of a formal model. A sample of 300 MTurk workers will be exposed to one of 8 treatment conditions in the experimental setting. While MTurkers are not the ideal frame for my target population — elite decisionmakers — the effects are believed to generalize. Power analysis suggests that 300 subjects will ensure detection of a treatment effect well below the substantive effect envisioned by the theory. I temporarily raise the significance level to account for the possibility of a lower effect size than anticipated; the significance level will be set at a more conservative level of p=0.05 in followup studies when the proper sample size is calibrated.

registration_responses.q1: Anticipatory Arms Control: Explaining Preemptive Constraints on Breakthrough Military Technologies
registration_responses.q5: Michael Aklin, Clifford Bob, Alessandra Casello, Alexandra Chinchilla, Miguel Gomez, Donald P. Green, Kolby Hanson, Kyle Haynes, Sunshine Hillygus, James Hollyer, Robert Jervis, Danielle Jung, Joshua Kertzer, Nadiya Kostyuk, Susan Landau, Tolya Levshin, Erik Lin-Greenberg, Hanzhang Liu, Asaf Lubin, Rose McDermott, Andrew Nathan, John Patty, Kathleen E. Powers, Georgiy Syunyaev, Alexander Thompson, Jeff Taliaferro, Brandon Valeriano
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: Scholars have long been aware of the strategic choices made by states when negotiating new international agreements. A rich literature focuses on concerns that adversaries will later renege on agreements. Using a formal model, I show that even in the best case scenario, when mutual trust is high (i.e. cheating occurs with probability zero), arms control deals may still fail. There exist several cases where technological breakthroughs were successfully regulated in anticipation of their respective demonstration points, sometimes while still in the design phase, or even prior to proof of concept. I advance a theory about a distinct mechanism: uncertainty about how frontier technologies might alter the security environment in unknown, and perhaps disadvantageous, ways. This theory would help explain systematic variation in the regulatory time horizon for new military technologies. The experiment I propose would test whether the hypotheses are validated more generally beyond the handful of historical case studies I discuss in the paper.
registration_responses.q16: Research Question: Assuming neutral priors on the future utility of a (potentially) disruptive weapons system innovation, how do (1) expected adoption capabilities, (2) expected diffusion propensities, and (3) revealed information about utility influence support for arms control? Hypothesis 1: Support for arms control should increase when the weapon originates with an adversary, and decrease when originates in a respondent’s home country. Hypothesis 2a: When a weapon originates in an adversary country, support for arms control should increase when expectations that it will diffuse are low, and decrease when expectations are high. Hypothesis 2b: When a weapon originates in a respondent’s home country, support for arms control should increase when expectations that it will diffuse are high, and decrease when expectations are low. Hypothesis 3: When a weapon is revealed to provide a disproportionate strategic advantage to a respondent’s country, support for arms control should decrease. When it conveys a disadvantage, support for arms control should increase.
registration_responses.q17: The study will involve a pair of experiments: first, a 2x2 factorial experimental design, followed by a standard two-condition design meant to test the second stage of a formal model. A sample of 300 MTurk workers will be exposed to one of 8 treatment conditions in the experimental setting. While MTurkers are not the ideal frame for my target population — elite decisionmakers — the effects are believed to generalize. Power analysis suggests that 300 subjects will ensure detection of a treatment effect well below the substantive effect envisioned by the theory. I temporarily raise the significance level to account for the possibility of a lower effect size than anticipated; the significance level will be set at a more conservative level of p=0.05 in followup studies when the proper sample size is calibrated.

attributes.title: Priming Empathy through Family History to Increase Support for Immigrants and Immigration

q1.value: Priming Empathy through Family History to Increase Support for Immigrants and Immigration

q2.value: Scott Williamson | Claire Adida | Adeline Lo | Melina Platas | Lauren Prather | Seth Werfel

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: As anti-immigrant political parties have gained strength in recent years, scholars have increasingly attempted to identify strategies for reducing hostility toward migrant communities. This study builds on a nascent literature that leverages emotion to shift such attitudes by focusing on the ability of empathy to produce more favorable attitudes toward immigrants and pro-immigration policies. Specifically, we test whether priming American respondents on the immigrant history of their own families can increase support for immigration, and we evaluate whether heightened empathy is the mechanism that underlies any attitudinal shifts.

q16.value: We expect that respondents primed to think about the immigrant histories of their own families will demonstrate more favorable attitudes toward immigrants and immigration. We also expect that these attitudinal shifts will be facilitated by greater feelings of empathy toward immigrants.

q17.value: We test these hypotheses with a survey experiment in which respondents are randomly assigned to receive a prime about their family history before or after answering questions about their attitudes toward immigrants and immigration. We evaluate the empathy mechanism using various strategies for mediation analysis.

registration_responses.q1: Priming Empathy through Family History to Increase Support for Immigrants and Immigration
registration_responses.q2: Scott Williamson | Claire Adida | Adeline Lo | Melina Platas | Lauren Prather | Seth Werfel
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: As anti-immigrant political parties have gained strength in recent years, scholars have increasingly attempted to identify strategies for reducing hostility toward migrant communities. This study builds on a nascent literature that leverages emotion to shift such attitudes by focusing on the ability of empathy to produce more favorable attitudes toward immigrants and pro-immigration policies. Specifically, we test whether priming American respondents on the immigrant history of their own families can increase support for immigration, and we evaluate whether heightened empathy is the mechanism that underlies any attitudinal shifts.
registration_responses.q16: We expect that respondents primed to think about the immigrant histories of their own families will demonstrate more favorable attitudes toward immigrants and immigration. We also expect that these attitudinal shifts will be facilitated by greater feelings of empathy toward immigrants.
registration_responses.q17: We test these hypotheses with a survey experiment in which respondents are randomly assigned to receive a prime about their family history before or after answering questions about their attitudes toward immigrants and immigration. We evaluate the empathy mechanism using various strategies for mediation analysis.

attributes.title: Voting for parliamentary rebels as expressive act

q1.value: Voting for parliamentary rebels as expressive act

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: In a previous study, “Who Likes Rebels? Representation and the Electoral Success of Parliamentary Mavericks (Registered with EGAP)” we find that voters express a preference for rebellious MPs that is not driven by considerations of norms to vote with the party or whether the rebel activity runs counter to the preferences of the public/constituency. We hypothesised that the observed behavior is rather driven by voters' expressive preferences and voting for a rebel should be seen as symbolic act. In this second study, we focus on identifying rebellion as expressive symbolic act. We implement a survey experiment to separate expressive from instrumental motivations behind vote choice. Respondents are presented with a series of five hypothetical MP. The experiment vignettes contains two parts: Part 1 describes a parliamentary vote in which an MP may or may not rebel against his/her party and which further varies in the subject of the bill (i.e., immigration, taxation/spending, environmental protection), whether the bill passed, whether the public supported or opposed the bill, the gender of the MP, and whether the MP was pivotal. The attribute realisations describing the context vary randomly across the five vignettes shown to each respondent and vary randomly across respondents (creating a conjoint experimental set-up). In part 2, the context of the vote is further described by whether the hypothetical MP represents Labour or Conservative party (party identity mechanism), whether the MP usually has much influence in parliament (protest vote mechanism), whether the MP claims that his/her vote represents the wish of the people (social identity mechanism), and whether the vote of the MP is in line with the respondents stated position on the issue subject of the bill (instrumental mechanism). The outcome measure asks respondents whether they would vote for such an MP in the general election.

q16.value: We test for four mechanism behind voting for a rebel: - protest vote mechanism (attribute condition: MP does not have much influence) - party identity mechanism (attribute condition: MP shares party ID with respondent) - social identity mechanism (attribute condition: MP says his/her vote represents the people) - instrumental mechanism (attribute condition: MP’s vote aligns with respondents’ issue position)

q17.value: We identify the explanatory power of a mechanism on preference for a rebel by estimating the marginal mean on the rebel attribute (the MP voted against his/her party) when either of the attribute conditions are met for that mechanism and compare that marginal mean to the marginal means on rebel associated with the other mechanism. Comparison of marginal means are implemented with difference-in-means test and standard errors clustered at the respondent-level.

attributes.title: Public Support for a Trade Dispute: Survey Experiments in South Korea and Japan

q1.value: Public Support for a Trade Dispute: Survey Experiments in South Korea and Japan

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Several on-going trade disputes have renewed scholarly and societal attention to the politics of trade disputes. Such on-going high salience trade disputes provide an invaluable opportunity to examine an old question of what drives public support or opposition to trade disputes, and in turn, whether the disputes serve the political interests of the incumbent. We examine the questions with the case of the recent Japan/South Korea trade dispute. We argue that the case of Korea-Japan dispute can illuminate several under-examined sources of variation in popular support for trade disputes. A large number of studies have already examined this issue, but in our opinion, the following factors have not been sufficiently considered in the literature: 1) Information on strategic interactions between the initiator and the target; 2) Information on international-legal endorsement/condemnation; and 3) Interactions of these factors.

q16.value: We thus propose to test the following main hypotheses: - Those who receive information that the adversary government de-escalates the dispute are more likely to oppose the trade dispute than those who receive information that the adversary government escalates the dispute. - Those who receive information that citizens of the adverse party want the dispute to be resolved (i.e., dovish public) are more likely to oppose the dispute than those who receive information that the public in the adverse party is fully on board with the dispute (i.e., hawkish public). - Those in the initiator country who receive information that their government's measure is illegal are more likely to prefer de-escalating the trade dispute than those who receive information that the restriction is legal. - Those in the target country who receive information that the initiator government's measure is legal are more likely to prefer de-escalating the trade dispute than those who receive information that the restriction is illegal. - Primary drivers of the public support for trade disputes differ between the two countries.

q17.value: To test the hypotheses, we conduct surveys in South Korea and Japan in August 2019 by using the same survey design. To examine the multidimensionality about the relationship between the variables of our interest and popular support for trade disputes, we embed a conjoint experiment in the surveys. We adopt forced-choice conjoint methods and the experiment is designed to gauge which attribute respondents are the most concerned with for the trade dispute. More specifically, after showing a pair of hypothetical scenarios, we ask respondents under which scenario they are more likely to support distinct reactions of their own country: 1) government's export restriction; 2) government's position on the forced labor issue; and 3) civil society's boycott.

attributes.title: Exceptionalism and Exemptionalism: Framing U.S. Public Opinion on the International Criminal Court

q1.value: Exceptionalism and Exemptionalism: Framing U.S. Public Opinion on the International Criminal Court

q5.value: I wish to thank Heidi Nichols Haddad, Christian Axboe Nielsen, and Nicholas Weller for inspiring this inquiry,, and Stephen Chaudoin, Gabrielle Cheung, Dennis Chong, Hannah Garry, Benjamin Graham, R. Joseph Huddleston, Tom Jamieson, Patrick James, Gerardo Munck, Mark Paradis,, and Wayne Sandholtz for their invaluable advice and comments on earlier drafts., I gratefully acknowledge research grants, from the Center for International Studies and the Program in Political Science and International Relations, used to field the experiments, and the USC Provost Fellowship in the Social Sciences., In addition, this material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Program under Grant No. DGE-1418060., Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: (response to this field was updated on June 15, 2018) Scholars argue that the U.S. is unlikely to join international organizations (IOs) unless it can exercise significant control over them. Yet, by focusing on the government position, they neglect the public’s potentially divergent views and its ability to pressure policy change. The Interna- tional Criminal Court (ICC)—which has been the subject of much scholarly and policy debate, and represents one of the most important IOs the U.S. could join but has yet to join—provides a useful site of inquiry for public and elite position alignment. Recent surveys of U.S. adults report increasing support of the ICC and U.S. membership. This paper investigates if public opinion differs from policy because the public responds differently from elites when presented with positive and negative issue frames regarding the Court. Drawing on experimental work in the American politics subfield, particularly the framing literature, I derive and test theory regarding factors likely to influence support for the ICC and U.S. membership. Relative to individuals in the control treatment, I expect that participants exposed to positive (negative) frames will increase (decrease) their support of the ICC and U.S. membership. I additionally test competing hypotheses from the framing literature regarding the effect of exposure to both positive and negative (i.e., competitive) frames.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 Information Participants who receive information about the ICC, namely its goals and jurisdiction, will be more likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive no prior information. Hypothesis 2 American Exceptionalism Participants who receive an American exceptionalism cue, concerning the United States’ historical support of international courts and tribunals, as well as discussion of the importance of future leadership, will be more likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 3 American Exemptionalism Participants who receive an exemptionalism frame, namely the possibility of the ICC overtaking U.S. investigations and prosecutions for serious crimes, as well as discussion of sovereignty/jurisdiction concerns, will be less likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 4 The Neutralizing Effect of Competitive Frames Participants who receive competing exemptionalist and exceptionalist cues will be neither more likely nor less likely to support the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 5 The Moderating Effect of Competitive Frames Participants who receive competing exemptionalist and exceptionalist frames will be less exemption- alist and exceptionalist than those exposed to only a single frame, but more exempetionalist and exceptionalist than those who receive the control treatment.

q17.value: Analysis of the experimental results was conducted through difference-in-means comparisons, as well as ordinary least squares (OLS) regression. These help me assess the average treatment effect of each frame on attitudes towards the U.S. becoming a member of the ICC.
